Previously we have found good support for the sample-size model, or a power law model with attention demanding stimuli, in twochoice VWM tasks using either signal detection theory or two-choice diffusion models. The analysis of Bays and colleagues implies that similar effects should be found in memory precision in continuous-outcome tasks (Tomić & Bays, 2024).

Our results showed separable effects of color saturation and set size on the parameters of the JP-CDM. When the stimulus and color wheel were both saturated the set-size effect was well described by the sample-size model, with a slight deviation for a minority of subjects in Experiment 2, which may reflect the nonlocality of the decision task. These results are consistent with the idea that VWM comprises a limited capacity resource represented by a population of noisy evidence samples that are recruited during stimulus encoding and distributed among items in memory. The fact that JP precision was worse for all set sizes with a larger range of items in Experiment 2 than with a smaller range in Experiment 1 highlights the overall metabolic costs of VWM encoding and the fact that encoding is an effortful process, as originally envisaged by Kahneman (1973). The sample-size interpretation of the set-size effect is that increasing set size makes VWM representations noisier because they are each based on fewer samples. These changes in internal noise produce changes in the memory distribution that resemble those produced by external chromatic noise in the identification task of .

The magnitude of the set-size effect increased when stimulus saturation was varied, and was better described by a power law with an exponent β > 0.75. In two-choice VWM tasks, large exponents are related to the use of attention-demanding stimuli and are predicted by an attention-weighted sample-size model in which samples are allocated unequally among the items in memory . We have not attempted to implement an attention-weighted version of the JP-CDM to avoid further complicating an already complex model, but the occurrence of larger exponents with desaturated stimuli is consistent with the idea that encoding them is attention demanding. The likely reason is because the proportion of the primary hue is reduced in desaturated colors, effectively reducing the signal-to-noise ratio, making them more attention demanding to encode. This interpretation is supported by the fact that the data for some subjects were better fitted by a two-β model with a larger value for desaturated than for saturated stimuli.

We did not need to invoke a guessing process of any kind to account for our data. The polar variability in memory was well described by the JP distribution for all set sizes, including m = 6 in Experiments 2 and 3, with sample-size or power law precision. The larger set size exceeds the typical estimates of the slot limit in slots-plus-guessing models and is where guessing is most likely to occur. We remain skeptical about the utility of guessing as a theoretical construct and note that in the variable precision model of van den Berg et al. (2014), for example, guessing ceases to be well-defined. In their model, an item may be in memory but be represented with very low precision (cf. their Figure 9), in which case the decision maker will have essentially no information about it. Alternatively, it may not be in memory, in which case the decision maker will again have no information about it. The latter decision is a guess; the former is not, but the distinction has no behavioral consequences.

The fact that van den Berg et al. (2014) found their data were best-fit with a Poisson encoding model -which predicts guessing on a proportion of trials -likely says more about the mathematical structure of their model than about the role of guessing in memory per se; specifically, it reflects the amount of probability mass their model puts in the tails of the error distributions. Their particular representation of variable precision, which consisted of a mixture of von Mises components with gamma-distributed precision parameters, although it predicts heavy tails, did not predict the tails as well as did a similar model augmented with a guessing component. We adopted the JP distribution to model polar variability in memory based on the results of who showed that with a large negative value of the shape parameter, ψ, it made equivalent predictions to an encoding-failure model that predicts uniformly distributed errors on a proportion of trials. The shape parameter of the JP distribution plays the same role in the JP-CDM model of VWM as it does in stimulus identification, namely, it allows the model to predict a proportion of very inaccurate responses. Whether or not these responses are viewed as "guesses" is more a matter of taste than theoretical substance, because they emerge as a natural consequence of the representational assumptions of the model without the need to invoke a mixture of memory-based and guessing processes.

The distinction between memory-based and guessing processes, which is partially abolished in the variable precision model, is wholly abolished in the population code models, which we characterized in the Introduction as the third wave of VWM theories. Instead of guessing, these models assume that the probability mass in the tails of the error distribution arises from noise in an array of tuned detectors. The peak of the tuning function decreases with set size, which increases the probability that a detector far from the peak will respond most strongly, increasing the likelihood of very inaccurate responses.

Although the JP-CDM is in broad agreement with the population code models in abolishing the distinction between memory-based responses and guessing, the models parameterize the effects of set size in different ways. The JP-CDM parameterizes the set-size effect via the inverse CSD of the JP distribution. This is consistent with the idea that the sample-size model is fundamentally a theory of variance, as it is in the two-choice signal detection model, even though the set-size predictions in that model are expressed in terms of d ′ . In contrast, in the population code models the shape of the tuning function remains invariant while its peak amplitude changes with set size. In the TCC model, the error distribution is represented by a similarity gradient that is invariant with set size and a set-size dependent d ′ parameter. Oberauer (2023) likewise found that the most parsimonious representation of data in the population code models was one in which the width of the tuning function -represented either by the concentration of a von Mises distribution or exponential decay in a Laplace distribution -remained invariant, while the amplitude changed.

In agreement with Oberauer's (2023) results, in a companion project to the present one, Qian et al. (2024) investigated the class of measurement models studied by Oberauer, focusing particularly on his preferred Gumbel-max model, and found evidence for a samplesize relationship expressed in the amplitude of the tuning function. If the inferred tuning function is the aggregate of many independent, individual, neural tuning functions, with the same centers but random amplitudes, whose number depends on set size, then such a relationship is theoretically plausible. Given the differences in the way the sample-size relationship is expressed in the JP-CDM and the population code models, a fruitful avenue for further research would be to combine the CDM with one or more of the population code memory models and to investigate how the set-size effect is expressed when the model is used to predict drift rates.

Recently, Fennell and Ratcliff (2023) proposed another approach to modeling the speed and accuracy of decision making in VWM based on Ratcliff's (2018) SCDM model. The SCDM is an alternative way to extend diffusion models to continuous-outcome decisions. The CDM, used here, can be viewed as a generalization of the original diffusion model of Ratcliff (2018), in which evidence is accumulated by a single signed process, in which the sign of the drift rate encodes the identify of the stimulus. The CDM extends the same idea to two evidence dimensions. The SCDM can be viewed as extending the class of parallel, racing diffusion models, which includes the dual diffusion models Ratcliff et al, 2007;Smith, 2023) and the leaky competing accumulator model (Usher & McClelland, 2001), in which each choice alternative is represented by own accumulator. The SCDM extends the idea of parallel accumulators to the continuum limit, in which the accumulating evidence is represented by a Gaussian random process with a prescribed correlation function, which smoothes the function and makes responses at adjacent points similarly probable. Instead of a scalar or vector-valued drift rate, as assumed in the original diffusion model and the CDM, respectively, the drift rate in the SCDM is a continuous function, which determines how rapidly evidence accumulates for each of the choice alternatives. In the model in its current form, the drift rate follows a normal distribution with a prescribed standard deviation and a stimulus-dependent amplitude that varies across trials. Evidence is accumulated until the process reaches a criterion level, analogous to the radius of the criterion circle in the CDM. The point at which the process first reaches the criterion determines the response and the time taken to reach it determines the decision time. Unlike the CDM, there are no explicit expressions for the RT and accuracy distributions for the SCDM and its predictions must be evaluated by simulation. Fennell and Ratcliff (2023) applied the SCDM to several color VWM experiments in which responses were made using eye movements, a mouse, or a touch screen, focusing on what we have termed "first wave" theories, comprising slots, resources, and guessing. They found the SCDM gave a good account of the RT and error data when the driftrate amplitudes and decision criteria both varied with set size and the memory process was augmented with guessing, represented as a Gaussian process with a zero drift-rate function, in which evidence accumulation was driven by noise alone. Like the free-κ models we reported here, they did not constrain the amplitudes of the drift rate functions, but they reported that the set-size amplitudes followed a power law with exponents that varied from 0.5 to 1.0, depending on the memory model, in agreement with the JP-CDM estimates reported here. They argued that trial-to-trial criterion setting is possible in VWM because the set size is known at the beginning of the retention interval, prior to the cue that initiates evidence accumulation. Allowing criteria to vary with stimuli relinquishes one of the core selective influence assumptions of evidence accumulation models, as we noted earlier. Somewhat counterintuitively, criteria were lower with large set sizes, suggesting that people become less conservative in their criterion settings as the task gets harder rather than more conservative. In contrast, in the JP-CDM, we were able to retain the selective influence assumption that decision criteria are independent of stimulus discriminability.

Although Fennell and Ratcliff (2023) focused on first-wave memory models, there is a natural correspondence in the representational assumptions of the SCDM and the population code models, which we termed third-wave theories, because both it and they assume that memory is represented as a continuous array of noisy detectors. The max-rule used in the signal detection models considered by Oberauer (2023) corresponds closely to the first-finishing decision rule in the SCDM, and the normally-distributed drift rate function in the SCDM likewise corresponds to the von Mises tuning function in his models. Potentially, then, versions of the SCDM with Laplace tuning functions could be considered and compared, allowing the SCDM to be brought into contact with the full range of population code models. Here, we adopted the JP distribution as a front end for the CDM because of its flexibility and to avoid restricting ourselves to a specific VWM model, but versions of the CDM in which it is combined with population code models would also be of theoretical interest. We see these possibilities as fruitful directions for future research.

Another potentially fruitful future direction, intersecting the previous one, would be to compare the CDM and SCDM as models of decision making in other tasks. As we noted above, these two models generalize the two main classes of diffusion models, single accumulator and racing accumulator models, respectively, to the continuum. In two-choice decisions, models of both classes have been shown to give good accounts of choice probabilities and RT distributions and have proven difficult to distinguish in data with any certainty (Smith, 2023). There have been many fewer applications of diffusion models to continuous-outcome tasks compared to the voluminous literature on two-choice tasks, but the published applications suggest that both models can provide good accounts of choice probabilities and RT distributions. The lack of explicit expressions for the SCDM means direct comparison of it and the CDM presents some methodological challengesit precludes maximum-likelihood fitting of the SCDM, for example, although there are approximation methods that might be extended to continuous-outcome tasks (Turner & Sederberg, 2012). The results of such a comparison would be informative, both in their own right and as an aid to the characterization of VWM retrieval as a decision process. The combination of different memory models and different decision models represents a rich and untapped vein of possibilities for future research.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this article we have sought to reframe the continuous-outcome VWM task as a decision task and to apply a model of continuous-outcome decisions, the CDM, to model the RT and error distributions from this task. We used a stimulus saturation manipulation to decouple the difficulty of the decision task from the difficulty of the memory task and showed that the speed and accuracy of retrieval decisions were well described by the JP-CDM, in which the polar variability of memory follows a Jones-Pewsey distribution. This distribution includes other models of memory variability, like the von Mises distribution, as special cases. We found that drift rates norms in the CDM, which determine rates of evidence accumulation, were lower when the decision task required matching across saturation levels, independent of the memory load in the task. The set-size effect was well described by either a sample-size model or a power-law model in the CSD, depending on whether saturation levels varied. The sample-size model implies that VWM is a limited capacity resource comprised of a population of noisy evidence samples that are shared among items in memory. When the evidence samples are allocated unequally, as occurs when one or more items captures attention, a power-law relation is predicted. Our results are consistent with a statistical model of resources of this kind. Our data were well described by a JP distribution with a large negative exponent, which predicts very inaccurate memory representations on some trials. This form of variable precision allowed us to account for the heavy tails of the error distribution without an explicit guessing process. The JP-CDM we have proposed here links VWM retrieval theoretically to continuous-outcome and two-choice decision tasks in other settings where diffusion models have been successfully applied. The success of the JP-CDM points towards a common process that underlies the speed and accuracy of decisions in discrete and continuous tasks in both perception and memory.

the two experiments, five in Experiment 1 (three females, two males) and five in Experiment 2 (two females, three males). Three subjects served in both experiments; three of them were associated with the laboratory; one is an author (PG). The remaining subjects were volunteers who were paid $A15/session for their participation. All subjects had normal visual acuity and normal color vision and served in multiple experimental sessions, each of around 50 minutes duration.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: The experimental sessions were run individually in a dimly-lit booth. The Eyelink II provides automatic calibration and drift-correction procedures, and we verified during pilot testing that it reliably recorded the endpoints of eye movements made to targets on the circumference of a circle of the same diameter as the color wheel. The calibration procedure required subjects to fixate on each of nine fiducial markers on the screen in turn and was carried out at the start of the session and repeated at the start of each 48-trial block. The subject's eye position was shown on an external monitor outside the experimental booth where it could be assessed for calibration and drift artifacts by the experimenter.

Each subject completed 10 experimental sessions, each of 160 trials, yielding a total of 1,600 trials per subject, 400 in each of the set size conditions. Subjects were instructed to fixate on a central cross on the display at the beginning of each trial and maintain fixation until they had made a decision. Once fixation was achieved, the stimulus display, consisting of 1, 2, 3, or 4 color patches in Experiment 1 or 1, 2, 4, or 6 color patches in Experiment 2, was presented for 300 ms. At the end of a 900 ms retention interval, a probe stimulus instructed subjects to recall the color of the patch presented at that location. They expressed their decisions by making saccadic eye movements to points on the color wheel that corresponded to the remembered colors. Reaction time (RT) was measured as the first time that deflection of the eyes exceeded 90% of the distance from the fixation point to the inner circle of the color wheel, and the response was taken as the location of the first corrective fixation after the eyes had crossed the inner circle.

div.head: Stimuli and Apparatus
div.p: Experiments 3 and 4 were programmed in JSpsych-Javascript under Windows 7 on a Dell Precision T1700 computer and were presented on a Philips 273V7 monitor running at a resolution of 1920 ×1080 at a refresh rate of 60 Hz. The stimuli were square color patches in Experiment 3 and circular patches in Experiment 4, subtending 0.97 • of visual angle, presented on a black background, and were equidistantly positioned on an imaginary circle subtending 4.7 • of visual angle. The stimuli were generated in Matlab in CIELUV space to ensure a constant luminance as color saturation varied and were viewed in a dimly-lit room.

Experiment 3 presented either high or low saturation colors, and subjects always responded on a high saturation color wheel. Experiment 4 factorially varied the saturation of the stimuli and the color wheel. The color wheel was an annulus of width 2.12 • and inner radius of 12.19 • . The color wheel was rotated randomly at the start of each experimental session and again at its midpoint. High saturation colors were centered at the CIELUV white-point (L = 54, U = 0.0037, V = −0.0275) with a UV radius of 127.97, while low saturation colors had a UV radius of only 51.59. Color sets comprised 360 colors selected at one-degree increments and converted to RGB for online display in the JSpsych-Javascript environment. Experiment 3 presented either 1, 2, 4, or 6 color patches in random order on each trial; Experiment 4 presented either 1, 2, or 4 color patches.

div.head: Subjects
div.p: Seven adults (three men and two women) ranging in age from 20 to 41 years, all with normal or corrected-to-normal visual acuity and normal color vision, served as subjects, five in each experiment. Three of the subjects served in both experiments. All of the subjects were affiliates of the Vision and Attention Laboratory at the University of Melbourne; two of them were authors (PG, ES). All subjects had normal visual acuity and served in 10 experimental sessions, each of around 50 minutes duration. Subjects in Experiments 3 and 4 completed 320 trials in each of 10 sessions, yielding a total of 3,200 trials per subject.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Subjects initiated each trial by clicking their mouse on a central "start trial" button, which was replaced by a white fixation cross (0.23 • visual angle), followed by an array of between 1 and 6 color patches in Experiment 3 or between 1 and 4 color patches in Experiment 4. In Experiment 3 the stimuli were displayed for 1,500 ms; in Experiment 4 the exposure duration was reduced to 400 ms to increase the difficulty of the decision task. At the end of the exposure period, the stimuli were extinguished and a 1,000 ms retention interval began. At the end of the retention interval, gray masks were displayed at each of the stimulus locations, one of which had a distinctive white border that acted as the report cue for the trial.

Subjects made their responses by moving the mouse from a central 1.26 • home circle to the point on the color wheel that matched their memory of the cued color. The response was the point at which the mouse first crossed the inner radius of the color wheel, and the RT was the time elapsing from the report cue to the time of the first inner radius crossing. Accuracy feedback was given on each trial via an exterior arc on the color wheel showing the subject's response relative to the target color for 1,000 ms before the trial ended. Fast and slow responses, defined as RTs shorter than 300 ms or longer than 3,000 ms, were penalized by a 4,000 ms timeout delay before the start of the next trial, accompanied by a text message explaining the reason for the penalty.

figure.head: Figure 2 :
figure.figDesc: Fit of the JP-CDM to data for one subject from the high noise condition of the chromatic noise decision task of Smith et al. (2020). (a) Marginal distributions of error and RT. (b). Q × Q plot of joint distribution. (c) Stimulus-dependent signed response errors and median RTs.

figure.head: Figure 3 :
figure.figDesc: Drift-rate bias model. (a) A stimulus presented at location θ is represented by a drift rate vector, ν θ . Drift-rate bias is represented by a set of bias vectors, b i . (b) The resultant drift rate is the vector sum of the drift rate associated with the stimulus and the nearest bias vector.(c) The drift-rate biases are exponentially decaying functions of the distance between the stimulus at θ and the bias vector at ϕ in the 1 − cos(•) circular distance metric. The total bias is the sum of the biases associated with each of the bias vectors. In the extended bias model the distancedependent bias, ν θ, bias , is decomposed into tangential and radial components, ν θ, tan. +δν θ, rad. , where δ parameterizes the radial component.

figure.head: Figure 4 :
figure.figDesc: Stimulus displays. All experiments used isoluminant stimuli in CIELUV space. The panel on the left shows the displays used in the eye-movement experiments (Experiments 1 and 2). A wider color wheel was used because subjects had to fixate on points on the wheel to express their responses and the overall luminance was lower because the experiments were run in neardark conditions. The panels on the right show the displays in the mouse-movement experiments (Experiments 3 and 4) that varied the color saturation of the stimuli and the wheel. Clockwise from top left: (a) desaturated four-element display; (b) desaturated six-element display with desaturated color wheel: (c) saturated display with saturated color wheel; (d) retrieval cue and post-trial feedback arc.

div.head: Stimuli and Apparatus
div.p: The experimental setup and stimulus display for Experiments 1 and 2 closely resembled the one used in the chromatic noise decision task of . The experiments were run on a pair of linked computers, one controlling a Cambridge Research Systems ViSaGe framestore that presented the stimuli with 12-bit color resolution and the other controlling an Eyelink II eye movement monitor with head-mounted infrared sensors that recorded responses. The stimuli were presented on a gamma-corrected 21" Sony Trinitron Multiscan CRT monitor with a resolution of 1024 × 768 px and a refresh rate of 100 Hz viewed from a distance of 100 cm. Stimulus presentation and response recording were carried out by custom C++ software. The stimuli were viewed in a near-dark room to facilitate eye-movement recording.

The stimuli were specified in CIELUV space, which is one of two isoluminant, equidiscriminability color spaces defined by the CIE in 1976(Wyszecki & Stiles, 1982pp. 164-169), the other being CIELAB space. Stimuli defined in these spaces have the properties of being isoluminant and, if they are separated by equal distances, equally discriminable. The two spaces are similar, but CIELUV space is thought to be superior for luminous devices like monitors and preserves the relative location of color hues as luminance changes, while CIELAB space is thought to be superior for reflective devices like offset printers and has less reliable hue positions across changes in luminance. The stimuli were circular color patches of 38 pixels (0.81 • ) diameter with colors chosen from a CIELUV white-point (L = 16, U = 0.1792, V = 0.4276) with a UV radius of 20, presented on a uniform gray background centered on the same white-point. The comparatively low values of the luminance coordinate and UV radius (cf. Experiments 3 and 4 below) were chosen to minimize screen glare when viewed under low-light conditions.

Experiment 1 presented either 1, 2, 3, or 4 color patches in random order on each trial; Experiment 2 presented either 1, 2, 4, or 6 color patches. The possible patch locations were equally spaced points on the circumference of an imaginary wheel of 72 pixels (1.5 • ) radius, centered on a 5 px fixation cross. On each trial, subjects were required to indicate the remembered hue of a color patch that was probed at the end of the retention interval and to express their decisions by making a saccadic eye movement from the fixation cross to a point on a surrounding color wheel. The color wheel was an annulus of width 1.5 • whose inner and outer circle subtended an angle of 6.1 • and 9.1 • , respectively. The wheel was rotated randomly after each 48-trial block.
